newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Metrobank in $50 mln borrowing.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Metrobank in $50 mln borrowing.

text.p: Metrobank of the Philippines launched a five-year US$50 million floating rate certificate of deposit deal into Asian debt markets on Wednesday.
The certificates were launched at par to float at 85 basis points over the three-month London Interbank Offered Rate. With fees, the all-in return to all management levels is 95 basis points.
Bankers Trust arranged the deal for Metrobank, the first five-year FRCD for a Philippine bank.

All of the other banks have tapped the market for three years, mostly successfully. Philippine bank deals has been popular because investors like the Philippines' economic story, and for a while at least, Philippine paper was relatively rare.
But bankers said spreads have come in significantly over the last year or so. At the same time, issuance has been stepped up, eroding the rarity value of Philippines issues.

"The spreads already have tightened so not as many banks are interested in Philippine paper as before," said one syndicate manager, adding that some banks aren't ready to take Philippine exposure out to five years.
With several bank issues already launched this year, "people may be a bit tired of Philippine names," he added.
Bankers also said the Metrobank deal is offering a scanty spread comapared with recent bank issues.
For example, the country's biggest bank Philippines National Bank earlier this month set a three-year FRCD that paid 81 basis points all-in, and some bankers said that deal is a hard sell.
State-held Land Bank of the Philippines is paying 90 basis over LIBOR for three-year paper.
But others pointed out that Metrobank, as the Philippines second-largest bank and its most profitable, may attract lenders eager to establish a relationship.
Hong Kong Chinese Bank set a US$50 million FRCD. The deal has puts and calls in years three and four and will float at 60 basis points over LIBOR.
With fees, the all-in return is 75 basis points.
Lippo Ltd holds a major stake in Hong Kong Chinese Bank.
